data.text: Contents
Introduction

The aim of isolation is to protect patients, staff and visitors by reducing the risk of the spread of potentially pathogenic micro-organisms. Transmission of a pathogen requires a source, a susceptible host and a route of transmission. Isolation precautions aim to interrupt these three elements by the physical segregation of the affected patient, and to prevent spread of infection to other patients, staff and relatives.
Regardless of the type of isolation the principles are the same:
To prevent spread of infection from person to person
To provide psychological support and reassurance to the patient and their families / carers in isolation
To ensure ALL staff are aware of and adhere to the correct precautions
To avoid unnecessary precautions
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Identify source / protective isolation procedures for the prevention and control of infection

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees (IPCCs) are responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.
The Chief Executive is ultimately responsible for ensuring that there are effective arrangements for infection prevention and control, including isolation management within the Trust

The Trust Board is collectively responsible for minimising the risks from infection to patients, staff members and the public. They are responsible for the general means by which the Trust controls such infection risks

The Trust Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) is responsible for ensuring that there are effective and appropriate arrangements for the prevention and control of infection throughout the Trust.

Head of Infection Control MSE- will give advice against this policy and ensure that all staff have access to this policy via the Trust Intranet and ensure that it is updated every two years or in line with current national guidance.

The Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice and support

Clinical managers (consultants, managers, and clinical departmental managers) are responsible for ensuring that the work performed by the staff they are supervising is performed in accordance with this policy. This follows the usual lines of professional accountability
All Staff - All Trust staff have a responsibility to adhere to Trust policy and ensure that appropriate measures are taken to reduce risks associated with infection
Categories of isolation
Isolation must not compromise the clinical care of the patient
There are two categories of isolation (Ayliffe 2009):
Source isolation: when a patient poses an infection risk to others
Protective isolation: when a patient is at risk of infection from others
Source isolation
5.5.1  Source isolation is the physical separation of one patient from another, in order to prevent nosocomial spread of infection.
Protective Isolation

5.6.1 Protective Isolation is the physical separation of patients who are immunocompromised / immunosuppressed in order to prevent the acquisition of infection or pathogens from other patients, staff or visitors.
In both categories

5.6.2 The decision to isolate a patient should be based on the infection risk to other patients, staff and visitors. A protective isolation notice is required and must be placed on the outside of the door, outlining the precautions required

5.6.3 In order to minimise the risks of anxiety which are often experienced by many isolated patients, a full explanation of the nature of infection, (including the symptoms, treatment and the rationale for the isolation measures), should be given to the patient. Offer the patient and/or relatives, the relevant patient information leaflet.
5.6.4 Daily assessment and evaluation of the need for on-going isolation precautions must take place and be documented within nursing and or medical records
5.6.5 The Infection Prevention and Control Team is available for advice and guidance
Source isolation (previously known as barrier nursing)

5.7.1  Source isolation is indicated for conditions such as MRSA, Clostridium difficile, ESBL (extended spectrum beta lactamase producing organisms), Chicken  Pox, Carbapenemase-producing organisms (CPO), and pulmonary tuberculosis, patients with diarrhoea and or vomiting, influenza (and respiratory viruses of concern) and fevers from the tropics in which an infectious cause cannot be ruled out.
Risk assessment

A dynamic risk assessment approach should be carried out. A Dynamic Risk assessment is the assessment of the factors that influence the transmission of a pathogen and its impact. It enables staff to prioritise the use of isolation facilities and must be done in collaboration with the Infection Prevention and Control Team, Ward Manager, patient's clinician and Clinical Site Manager.
When undertaking a risk assessment with the Infection Prevention and Control Team the following factors will be considered:
The classification of the pathogen and the ability to protect against or treat individual infections
The probable route of transmission and evidence of transmission
Susceptibility of other patients near to the infected /colonised patient in the same bay (i.e. do the other patients have open wounds or an invasive device)
Whether the organism is antibiotic resistant
Possible detrimental effects of isolation to the patient (i.e. risk of falls, confusion or depression), weighed against severity of the risk of transmission to other patients
Isolated patients may experience more anxiety and depression. Isolation may hamper rehabilitation. To reduce these risks, preparatory information should be given wherever possible

Regular assessment and evaluation of the situation, in conjunction with the Infection Prevention and Control Team, patient's clinician and Ward Manger is necessary to decide if isolation of the patient remains the most appropriate form of care

A single room must be allocated to patients who are risk assessed and the need for isolation identified. (Section 6.0). If there are no single rooms available in the immediate vicinity, consult the Clinical Site Manager for availability on another ward if appropriate.

Alternatives to single room isolation include barrier nursing the patient on the open ward or cohorting of patients with the same condition. As not all patients with similar symptoms (e.g. diarrhoea), have the same aetiology. Therefore, cohorting should only be carried out following a risk assessment and with guidance from the Infection Prevention and Control Team, Ward Manager and Director of Infection Prevention and Control.
Once the risk assessment has identified that a patient requires isolation, the following precautions must be considered:

Nurse the patient in a single room with the appropriate facilities available e.g. if the patient's source of infection is diarrhoea an en-suite facility would be preferable but, if not available, a dedicated commode must be allocated for the patient's sole use. Ensure thorough and frequent cleaning of the commode using the Trust approved cleaning and decontamination product.
Display a ‘Source Isolation' sign on the door to alert staff and visitors to the required precautions
Ensure that the isolation door remains closed. This is essential when airborne infection is suspected e.g. pulmonary TB, novel respiratory viruses
Limit the number of staff who come into contact with the patient to reduce the risk of transmission
The room must be cleaned daily with dedicated cleaning equipment
All non-essential equipment must be removed from the room before the patient is isolated
Where possible use dedicated equipment for isolated patients. Where this is not possible all equipment must be decontaminated between each patient use (see Decontamination Policy)
Maintain confidentiality at all times
Keep all charts and notes outside the room to reduce the risk of contamination
Set up the appropriate protective clothing outside the room i.e. disposable gloves, plastic aprons, alcohol hand sanitizer and specific equipment as required e.g. respiratory protection
Sharps bin to be kept inside the patient's room, if appropriate (managed in line with the sharps policy)
All waste that is contaminated with body fluids must be placed in an orange clinical waste bag in the room and removed immediately and taken to the waste hold

Linen to be placed into water soluble pink alginate bags and then placed in to a white plastic bag- This is NOT required for a MRSA patient's linen. This can be placed into white linen plastic bag only
Strict and thorough hand decontamination in accordance with the Hand Hygiene Policy
Encourage the patient to decontaminate their hands before and after entering the ward / room, after using the toilet and before eating
Visitors should be instructed to decontaminate their hands upon entry and leaving the ward / room

Relatives do not need to wear PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) i.e. gloves, aprons. They are only to be worn by relatives when appropriate, such as when carrying out ‘hands-on care' unless indicated through risk assessment in conjunction with the infection protection and control team.
Isolation precautions will be terminated following a risk assessment. This will be documented in the patient's clinical record (see 6)
Provide patients, relatives, carers with relevant information leaflets

Where possible, staff and visitors should be restricted to those who are non- susceptible to the condition e.g. chicken pox immune. If the infection does not fall within these categories, staff and visitors should be restricted to minimise the risk. The Infection Prevention and Control Team Department should be contacted for advice, as the needs to minimise infection risk may need to be balanced with clinical and compassionate considerations.
Transport of infected / infectious patients

Movement of infectious or potentially infectious patients should be kept to a minimum. When it is necessary to transport patients to other wards or departments, precautions to minimise the risk of transmission must continue

If it is possible to delay an investigation without adversely affecting the patient's management this should be considered. However, the presence of an infectious disease should not delay urgent clinical investigations
The receiving area must be informed prior to transfer to ensure that they have the appropriate precautions in place and that appropriate facilities are available

Patients with known or suspected infections must, as far as possible, be placed at the end of the list and not be left in waiting areas. This will allow adequate cleaning of the environment and equipment following the appointment reducing the risks to other patients
Check specific infection control policies and advice
Post isolation / death / discharge
*New patients must not be admitted to the room / bed space until it has undergone a terminal clean*
The room / bed space must be cleaned thoroughly by the bed turnaround Cleaning Team, once it is vacated
All unused disposable items which may be contaminated must be disposed of.

All equipment and belongings must be decontaminated before the patient comes out of isolation or prior to further use. It should also be labelled with an ‘I am clean label'. (Refer to Decontamination Policy)
The appropriate cleaning method for the room and the equipment will be determined by the organism. If a deep clean is required contact the Domestic Service Manager
Nurse in charge to allocate responsibility to clean the equipment prior to deep cleaning
In the case of death, the same principles are applied as in life. Ensure mortuary staff are appropriately informed of any infection risk
Protective isolation (previously known as reverse barrier nursing)

Protective isolation is intended to prevent a more susceptible patient acquiring infection. Immunocompromised patients vary in their susceptibility to infections, dependent upon the severity and type of immunosuppression. The measures that follow are to be done in addition to standard infection control precautions

A single room is required for neutropenic patients (neutropenia refers to a neutrophil count of <0.5). A room with positive pressure ventilation is desirable for patients who are estimated to have prolonged neutropenia i.e. >7days provided the patient does not have any evidence of a transmissible infection e.g. Meticillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) or active TB. The Clinical Site Managers will ill support placement when needed. Patients who are likely to be neutropenic and are susceptible of having one of the above may be nursed in a general/neutral pressure single room with the door closed.
If a single room is not available then a risk assessment must be undertaken to identify if patients are high priority and full protective isolation precautions must be implemented at all times.

HIV-infected patients who are immunocompromised (CD4 count <200) and admitted with a febrile illness require a single room for purposes of both protective and source isolation as they are susceptible to TB and or may already have TB. If their clinical condition dictates close monitoring and TB has been ruled out, they may be nursed on the main ward.
Preparation of a room prior to admitting a patient into protective
isolation
Single room floors must be cleaned before the patient is admitted using a clean mop head and appropriate coloured bucket and cleaning solution
Ensure that the hand wash sink is stocked with appropriate hand hygiene products
Ensure that plastic aprons and disposable gloves are available outside the room
Remove unnecessary equipment and furniture from the room to facilitate cleaning
Equipment in the isolation room must, as far as possible, be dedicated for the use of that patient

All equipment must be cleaned thoroughly with a Trust approved disinfectant agent e.g. Clinell Universal wipes prior to and following use. If an en-suite toilet is not available, then adjacent toilet or commode must be thoroughly cleaned using the appropriate agent (chlorine or peracetic acid based) and allocated for the dedicated use of the neutropenic patient.
Place a ‘Protective Isolation' laminated sign on the outside of the door
Discourage the patient from keeping unnecessary belongings in the room to enable effective cleaning to take place, balancing this with the patient's psychological needs
Patient's records must be kept outside the room to reduce the risk of contamination
Keep the door of the room closed, apart from the necessary entrances and exits, balancing the psychological care of the patient and the need for protective isolation
Care of the patient in protective isolation
General precautions
11.1.1 Hand decontamination: always wash hands with soap and water or alcohol hand sanitiser prior to entering and on leaving the isolation room
11.1.2 Plastic aprons must be worn by all staff and visitors if they are performing clinical care or assisting the patient with hygiene activities (not required for social visiting)
11.1.3 Gloves are not necessary except for aseptic procedures (sterile and non-sterile) and for patient contact unless there is likely exposure to blood or body fluids as per universal precautions
Staff
11.2.1 Ensure all staff are aware of the necessary precautions and the need to maintain normal standards of monitoring and care
11.2.2 Limit the number of staff entering the isolation room
11.2.3 Staff who are nursing patients with infections (i.e. source isolation), should avoid nursing patients in protective isolation during the same shift
Patient psychological care
11.3.1 Patients in protective isolation must receive psychological support and reassurance regularly throughout each shift
11.3.2 Involve specialist nurses as deemed necessary
11.3.3 Ensure patient has contact with outside world where possible such as newspapers
Visitors
11.4.1 Reduce the risk of cross infection by limiting the numbers of visitors - limit children
11.4.2 Discourage visitors with symptoms of infections or known exposure to infections e.g. chicken pox
11.4.3 Visitors must sit on the chair provided for visitors - not on the patient's bed
11.4.4 Educate visitors on hand hygiene and ask them to decontaminate their hands when visiting
11.4.5 Ensure awareness of restriction of gifts for the patient
11.4.6 Note- no flowers or plants as they may be a source of aspergillus or other fungal spores.
Linen and Clothing
11.5.1 Bed linen must be changed daily
11.5.2 Linen must be placed in pink alginate bags prior to being placed in a white plastic outer bag. (MRSA linen to be placed in a white plastic bag also)
11.5.3 Patients must be encouraged to change clothing daily
11.5.4 Disposable curtains in patient's room must be changed and dated on patient discharge / transfer
Patient Hygiene
11.6.1 Patients must receive education on good hygiene practices. This must include washing hands before eating and after using the toilet
11.6.2 Disposable single use wipes should be provided for washing
11.6.3 Face cloths / flannels must not be used unless they are sent home daily for laundering
11.6.4 Skin must be kept clean by daily bathing or washing
11.6.5 Patients may use the bath on the ward provided it is cleaned thoroughly before each patient use. No sharing of toiletries / equipment
Diet
11.7.1  Patients must not be given ice from ice making machines
Cleaning of patient's room
11.8.1 The protective single isolation room floor must be cleaned daily using a clean mop head
11.8.2 Water and mop head must be changed between each protective isolation single room
11.8.3 All horizontal surfaces and furniture must be damp dusted daily using Clinell Universal Wipes
11.8.4 Disposable gloves must be worn when cleaning the protective isolation room and hands washed on leaving the room
Protective isolation patients requiring investigations
11.9.1 Ideally investigations / procedures should be performed in the isolation room if possible
11.9.2 Visits to other departments should only occur with permission from medical staff or senior nursing staff
11.9.3 Patients should go directly to the department and return immediately the investigation is complete. Waiting in departments or in the corridors must be avoided
Routes of transmission

Direct Contact - organisms can be transmitted directly to susceptible people via contaminated equipment or by the hands of healthcare workers. It is therefore essential that hands are decontaminated before and after every episode of direct patient care, and that equipment is kept clean and dry and is decontaminated between each use
Airborne - organisms can be transmitted in dust or skin scales carried by the air during procedures such as bed making, or via respiratory droplets
Food borne - food poisoning occurs when contaminated foods are ingested

Blood borne - blood or blood-stained material is potentially hazardous and infection is transmitted via inoculation accidents, existing breaks in the skin, gross contamination of mucous membranes, sexual activity or across the placenta from mother to baby

Vector borne - disease via biting insects is currently not a major problem in the United Kingdom; however, insects such as cockroaches can carry pathogenic organisms on their bodies and in their digestive tracts. This may infect the hospital environment, including food and sterile supplies: therefore, storage of supplies in clean well ventilated areas is essential
Risk assessment of infections and the use of available single
rooms

Any patient, suspected or known to be colonised or infected with an infectious agent that may pose a risk to others, must be isolated in line with Risk Assessment. Due to the limited numbers of single rooms it is recognised that at times single rooms will need to be prioritised.
The following information will assist the risk assessment process:

Low risk. Single room or cohort bay.
No risk. May be nursed on an open ward.
Contact tracing may be required for these patients

data.text: Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates and Donning and Doffing updates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
